rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;31dc1819.1502">   <title>Announcement Decolonizing The Mind Summer School Amsterdam July 19-31 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;31dc1819.1502</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>The International Institute for Scientific Research has started a new and exciting project: the Decolonizing The Mind Summer School. The first edition is 2015 in Amsterdam.<br><br>The following information is available about the Summer School:<br><br>The most important information is the brochure with the detailed description of the Summer School: http://www.decolonizingthemind.org/download/DTMSM2015Brochure.pdf. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-14T22:17:20+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dew Baboeram</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;31dc1819.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;e808e8a.1412">   <title>Ohio University Press - Short Histories of Africa </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;e808e8a.1412</link>   <description> Dear AFRICAN-PROTEST subscribers,<br><br>We hope that these titles will be of interest.<br><br>[9780821421260]Thomas Sankara<br><br>An African Revolutionary<br>Ernest Harsch<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThomas Sankara: An African Revolutionary will serve as an excellent introduction to Sankara and the revolution in Burkina Faso and explain why Sankara continues to be so widely admired throughout Africa and beyond.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdChristopher Wise, author of Derrida, Africa, and the Middle East<br>Thomas Sankara, often called the African Che Guevara, was president of Burkina Faso, one of the poorest countries in Africa, until his assassination during the military coup that brought down his government. Although his tenure in office was relatively [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-12-08T11:17:17+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Charles Woodhead</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;e808e8a.1412</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;2c11ef58.1411">   <title>FYI African History Season ... Look Community Talk ... MSF Dinner Fundraisr </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;2c11ef58.1411</link>   <description> Greetings,<br><br>I trust you are well.<br><br>This is to put you in the loop of our activities:<br><br>1. In Harrow, north London our African History Season theme is 'Marcus<br>Garvey/UNIA @ 100: The Legacy'. Our next two events cover UNIA's<br>Enterprises (Nov 12) and Moving Forward with the UNIA Legacy (Dec 19,<br>flyer attached)<br><br>2. In Croydon, south London we mark African History Season/UNIA @ 100<br>with 'AfricanHistory+ @ Croydon', which covers music, history and the<br>Look How Far We've Come Community Talk (CT), which has a workshop<br>focusing on racism in Croydon (flyer attached) [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-11-01T21:51:04+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>BBM/BMC</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;2c11ef58.1411</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;3c1cb9f6.1410">   <title>Africa, Fourth Edition </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;3c1cb9f6.1410</link>   <description> [9780253012920_FChigh]&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/africa-fourth-edition&gt;Africa, Fourth Edition&lt;http://www.combinedacademic.co.uk/africa-fourth-edition&gt;<br>Edited by Maria Grosz-Ngat\ufffd\ufffd, John H. Hanson &amp; Patrick O'Meara<br>&quot;A remarkable textbook that reflects and explains the diversity, dynamism, and dilemmas of the contemporary African continent. The chapters are engaging and accessible; they explore a broad range of topics, from the legacies of colonialism to popular art and debates about human rights. Africans are depicted as neither victims nor victors, but men and women seeking connections, security, pleasure, and creativity in an ever-changing world. I am sure that Africa will quickly become the 'go-to' text for introductory classes in African studies.&quot; -Dorothy L. Hodgson, Rutgers University<br> [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-24T14:12:30+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Charles Woodhead</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;3c1cb9f6.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;6d147ed.1410">   <title>Complicty Conference </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;6d147ed.1410</link>   <description> CALL FOR PROPOSALS<br><br>COMPLICITY<br>A two-day conference exploring issues of complicity, organised by the University of Brighton's Understanding Conflict: Forms &amp; Legacies of Violence research cluster.<br><br>Tuesday 31st March \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Wednesday 1st April 2015<br>University of Brighton, UK<br><br>CALL FOR PAPERS<br>DEADLINE: 1st December 2014<br><br>The problem of complicity is a longstanding feature of everyday moral experience, and yet comparatively little work focuses explicitly on it. Furthermore, in an increasingly neo-liberal world, it is becoming increasingly difficult to avoid complicity both in its creation of a particular model of the person and with its attendant demands on how we live, [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-10-16T12:59:28+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ken Clarry</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;6d147ed.1410</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;bc8c0f0.1408">   <title>After 2015: Development and its Alternatives, 10th-11th September, British Academy, London </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;bc8c0f0.1408</link>   <description> ?<br><br>?Apologies for cross-posting<br><br>BRITISH ACADEMY CONFERENCE<br>After 2015: Development and its Alternatives<br>Wednesday 10 &amp; Thursday 11 September 2014<br>The British Academy, 10-11 Carlton House Terrace, London SW1Y 5AH<br>The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) will expire in 2015, with mixed results. This conference takes a social and political perspective on why development fails, and how local knowledge might inform a post-MDG environment more sensitive to those structurally disadvantaged by the global economy. Within mainstream debates there has been little room for the developmental alternatives lived by people in conditions of poverty and thus no space for exploring more critical [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2014-08-04T12:31:26+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Clive Gabay</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;bc8c0f0.1408</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;b8eb5325.1405">   <title>Community Development Journal Special Supplement: 'Commons Sense' </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;b8eb5325.1405</link>   <description> *We are pleased to announce the publication of:*<br><br>*Community Development Journal \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Special Supplement *(2014)<br><br>*Commons Sense*<br>*New thinking about an old idea*<br><br>http://cdj.oxfordjournals.org/content/49/suppl_1.toc<br><br>All articles permanently free to download<br><br>*Editors*<br>*Mary McDermott, Tom O\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdConnell *and* \ufffd\ufffdrla O\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDonovan*<br>Throughout the globe there is a blossoming of interest in the old idea of<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthe commons\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. For many, it offers a radical escape from the<br>all-too-apparent devastations of capitalism and the impoverishments of a<br>world possessed by the idea of possession. For these commoners, the commons<br>were not all lost with the European land enclosures of the sixteenth<br>century, but continue to [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2014-05-12T15:22:34+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Community Development Journal</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=AFRICANPROTEST;b8eb5325.1405</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
